en.value: I found this cool new place.
Describing our neighbourhood and giving recommendations - Prepositions of place and movement
It's just down the road
Here's a tip!

Let’s learn some more ways of talking in more detail about the area we live in. When we move to a new place, we’re bound to be asked plenty of questions about our surrounding neighbourhood. So to prepare ourselves for that, we’re going to learn things like:
He's found a nice house in the suburbs.
It's so peaceful here. It makes a nice change from the city.
The pharmacy is just around the corner.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
spot
I found a great new spot for coffee.
In this context, “spot” means the same as “place”. These words are interchangeable, and although “spot” is typically more colloquial than “place”, we can use either in most social contexts.
I found a great new spot for coffee.
We have a nice place for a picnic near the office.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
We have a nice [k]spot[/k] for a picnic nearby.
place
suburb
He's found a nice house in a suburb of New York.
neighbour
Have you met your neighbours?
We live in a beautiful [k]suburb[/k] in Amsterdam.
neighbour
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I've asked my ne[k]i[/k][k]g[/k][k]h[/k][k]b[/k][k]o[/k][k]u[/k]r to feed my cat.
Match the word to its meaning.
spot
suburb
neighbour
a particular place
an area on the edge of a city
someone who lives close to you
safe
Apparently, the area's very safe.
dangerous
Be careful walking alone at night. It can be dangerous.
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]This[/k] [k]area[/k] [k]is[/k] [k]dangerous[/k] [k]at[/k] [k]night.[/k]
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Don't worry.
Be careful.
This area's safe.
It can be dangerous.
crowded
There are so many people living here; it’s a bit crowded.
peaceful
It's so peaceful here. It makes a nice change from the city.
What does Ariana think about her suburb?
It is safe but crowded.
It is dangerous but peaceful.
It is modern and popular.
How is Olivier's new place?
The area can be dangerous at night.
It is always noisy and crowded there.
He can't think of a better place to live in.
When we show someone around our area or explain approximately where something is, we can use these expressions. They don’t literally mean what they say. They more-or-less mean “nearby”.
There's a bus stop just up the road.
around the corner
The pharmacy is just around the corner.
[k]The shop[/k] [k]is[/k] [k]just[/k] [k]around[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]corner.[/k]
up the road / down the road
There is a bus stop just up the road.
around
down / up
the corner
the road
There is a bus stop just [k]down[/k] the road.
up
The metro is just [k]u[/k][k]p[/k] the [k]r[/k][k]o[/k][k]a[/k][k]d[/k].
Where is the new coffee place?
The cafe is not far away.
It takes a long time to get to the cafe.
He doesn’t know where the cafe is.
local
We often meet at our local gym.
True or false?
She works at the local market.
The market is in the area where she lives.
dangerous
crowded
up the road
safe
peaceful
down the road
Here’s a quick recap of all the words and expressions we’ve learned. Have one more look before we practise some more.
spot / place
suburb
neighbour / neighbourhood
local gym / supermarket / shop
dangerous / safe area
crowded / peaceful area
around the corner
up the road / down the road
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Barbara and Rocco are sharing their moving experiences.
What is your new place like, Rocco?
It seems really nice and [k]peaceful[/k]. I love it. How about yours?
Pff, it's such a [k]crowded[/k] area.
Is it [k]safe[/k]?
It doesn't seem [k]dangerous[/k], but my neighbours are noisy sometimes.
That's too bad. I just met my [k]neighbours[/k] yesterday and they seem really nice.
How's the [k]local[/k] area? Have you found any good places?
Plenty! I've recently found this great new spot for coffee just [k]around the corner[/k] from my flat. You should come over!
Barbara
Rocco
Rocco's area is full of...
local places
noisy neighbours
local businesses
Is it [k]s[/k][k]a[/k][k]f[/k][k]e[/k] at night here?
Fill in the gap using the audio.
We've found a nice house [k]in the suburbs[/k].
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
In the evening the [k]place[/k] becomes really [k]crowded[/k].
neighbour
local
Have you met your [k]neighbours|neighbors[/k]?
Where is the nearest metro station?
The station is down the road.
The station is up the road.
The station is around the corner.
Type a word similar in meaning to "quiet".
It seems really nice and [k]peaceful[/k].
The market is just [k]up the road|down the road|around the corner[/k].
Where is the market? Type one of the expressions we've learned.
Type a word opposite in meaning to "safe".
Fairfield is the most [k]dangerous[/k] suburb of Sydney.
Can you recommend...?
Let's take a look at some verbs that are useful when we visit a new neighbourhood or city. We'll learn how to ask for and understand recommendations and tips with words like these:
to recommend
to discover
to avoid
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
to come across
I've come across a few nice bakeries here.
to find
I found a nice little deli round the corner.
I came across some lovely record stores in Lisbon.
This means the speaker happened to walk past some record stores.
She [k]found[/k] the ring at a second hand shop.
fought
Sometimes we come across something by chance; sometimes an especially nice place is not very-well known. We can call these places "finds" or "hidden gems". Have a look below for some examples.
What a great find!
Dunbar's Close Garden is one of Edinburgh's hidden gems.
This lake is a great find! It’s such a hidden gem.
This sentence talks about a place that is very special but was only found by accident.
to recommend
My neighbour recommended it to me.
to discover
I discovered a beautiful little square in the old town.
My neighbour recommended a restaurant to me.
The neighbour told her about a restaurant he likes.
Select the words that have a similar meaning to "to find".
My brother [h]came[/h] [h]across[/h] a lovely new café.
Can you recommend a good film?
She loves to [h]discover[/h] new countries.
to try
Have you tried that new restaurant yet?
to avoid
You should avoid the canal at night.
[k]Let's[/k] [k]try[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]swimming pool[/k] [k]near my house![/k]
When we give recommendations or advice to someone, we often use the expression "it's worth a try".
I've only heard good things about the cafe, I guess it's worth a try.
She's not sure if filing a complaint helps, but thinks it is worth a try.
Select the correct option.
I think it's worth a try.
I think it's worth to try.
I think its worth is a try.
You should avoid taking the metro between 7am and 9am.
This sentence recommends taking the metro in the morning.
This recommends not getting on the metro at that time.

As we've just seen, we can advise someone to avoid a certain place or thing: "avoid" + (the / a) noun But we can also talk about avoiding certain actions. To do this, we just add the -ing form of the verb right after the word "avoid": "avoid" + -ing form Have a look at some examples.
You should avoid taking the metro.
I avoided eating out for a while to save money.
He avoids walking down the canal at night.
[k]You[/k] [k]should[/k] [k]avoid[/k] [k]taking[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]metro.[/k]
We [k]avoided[/k] [k]taking[/k] the car because it's difficult to park in the city centre.
annoyed
take
The same works for recommending certain actions. To do this, we just add the -ing form of the verb right after the word "recommend": "recommend" + -ing form Have a look at some examples.
I recommend walking through the old town.
She recommends booking a table.
You recommended hiking to the top of the mountain.
She recommends walking through the old town.
This is a recommendation for an activity.
Complete the sentence to give a recommendation.
You should [k]try[/k] the Greek place on the corner.
be
Match the words with their definitions.
to discover a place by accident
to tell someone what you think they should do
to not do a certain thing
It's definitely worth [k]a[/k] [k]try[/k]!
to
trying
Can you [k]r[/k][k]e[/k][k]c[/k]o[k]m[/k]mend some restaurants in the area?
Listen to the audio. Which statement is correct?
We hear what someone stayed away from.
We hear a recommendation.
We hear about a hidden gem.
My dad [k]discovered[/k] a nice beach on his walk.
discussed
Have you [k]come[/k] [k]across[/k] any nice bakeries here?
cut
around
Complete the sentence to say what you've discovered.
I [k]found[/k] the most delicious bakery last week.
tried
What can we say to describe a place that is especially nice but not well-known or hard to find?
hidden gem
hanging germ
hopping gene
There are very few parking spots in the city centre. We should [k]avoid taking[/k] the car.
I [k]found|came across|discovered[/k] the most delicious sushi place yesterday.
What can we say to express that we've discovered something by chance?
come across
came about
cried around
I've [k]come across[/k] a few nice bakeries here.
I think you should [k]try[/k] one of the vegetarian dishes, they're really good here.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I [k]recommend[/k] leaving early to be on time.
[k]I[/k] [k]think[/k] [k]it's[/k] [k]worth[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]try![/k]
This lake is a great find! It’s such a [k]hidden gem[/k].
How can we say that we think something is a good idea?
I think it's worth a try.
I think you should avoid it.
I think it's worth a lot.
I think [k]it's worth a try[/k]!
I [k]discovered[/k] a beautiful little square in the old town.
You're the expert! Write or record yourself giving recommendations to someone visiting your city.

You should avoid the sightseeing tours for tourists. I would recommend walking around the city centre - you'll find some hidden gems that way! In the evening, try the Spanish tapas bar near the church for dinner.
Grammar: Prepositions of place and movement
Let's recap!
Let's take a look at some useful prepositions to talk about place and movement. First, let's recap some of the prepositions of place you may have already seen:
on: I left the keys on the table.
at: She's at the station now.
in: I left my bag in the car.
outside: Leave your dirty shoes outside the house.
behind: There is parking behind the supermarket.
in front of: There's a square in front of the cathedral.
next to: I parked my car next to yours.
between: We live between two shops.
I've parked just outside the restaurant.
This sentence tells us where something is.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
beside
I often sit beside the river and read a book.
We can also say "by". This has a similar meaning to "beside", and in a lot of cases, the two are interchangeable.
Can we have a table by the window?
Can we have a table beside the window?
opposite
There's an ATM opposite the station.
on the other side of
The hotel is on the other side of the river.
The cafe is [k]on[/k] the other side [k]of[/k] the park.
in
from
I live o[k]p[/k][k]p[/k][k]o[/k][k]s[/k][k]i[/k]te a block of flats.
Match each word with its opposite.
in front of
in
behind
outside
Now let's look at some prepositions of movement. These make us think less about a location and more about a route or a direction.
Let's go to the beach!
I usually run along the river.
She's just gone across the street.
You can't go through the park after 9pm.
around
The city centre is too busy. It's faster if we drive around it.
through
We can't walk through the park after 9pm.
We can't go through the park. We'll have to go [k]around[/k] it.
aloud
Be careful walking [k]t[/k][k]h[/k][k]r[/k][k]o[/k][k]u[/k][k]g[/k][k]h[/k] the city at night.
past
Keep going past the supermarket, the bank is on your left.
on the way to
Do we go past an ATM on the way to the restaurant?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Do you go past a post office [k]on the way[/k] to work?
in the way
[k]I'm just[/k] [k]walking[/k] [k]past[/k] [k]your[/k] [k]house![/k]
along
She often walks home along the river.
across
I have to walk across town to get to work.
I go [k]across[/k] the river every morning and evening.
between
into
He's gone into the bank.
In spoken English, it's common to say "in" instead of "into".
Get in the car!
I jumped in the pool.
Shall we go in the sea?
[k]Get[/k] [k]in[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]car.[/k]
There are some cases where we can say "inside", but not "in" and vice versa. Don't worry about the rules for now. Here are some examples which can take one but not the other.
I left my towel inside.
I live in a small town.
Did you leave your coat [k]inside[/k]?
in
Let's recap!
Here's a recap of the new prepositions we have just learned.
beside
opposite
on the other side of
around
through
past
on the way to
along
across
into
inside
[k]It's[/k] [k]on[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]way[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]the cinema.[/k]
The post office is just [k]beside|by|near[/k] the bank.
Complete the sentence with a word similar in meaning to "next to"
The traffic is awful in the city centre, so it's faster to go [k]around[/k] it.
through
I live [k]on[/k] the [k]other[/k] side of the park.
in
this
You shouldn't walk [k]through[/k] town on your own at night.
I'm just going [k]across[/k] the road. Back in 10 minutes.
on the way to
Do we go [k]past[/k] an ATM [k]on the way[/k]?
next to
across
There's a pharmacy just [k]o[/k][k]p[/k][k]p[/k][k]o[/k][k]s[/k][k]i[/k][k]t[/k][k]e[/k] the coffee shop.
I love running [k]along[/k] the beach in the evening.
It's so sunny and warm [k]outside[/k]!
inside
I just need to go [k]into[/k] the shop quickly.
Complete the sentence with the most likely preposition of movement.
Oh no, it's raining! Quick! Let's go [k]inside|in[/k].
